awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project from Howard University that establishes an I-Corps Site with Hampton University. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The Howard University I-Corps Site is a novel partnership involving two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), with assistance from the DC I-Corps Node, a regional I-Corps node supporting the DC-MD-VA region. The partnership supports enhanced participation of HBCU students and faculty from Howard and Hampton universities in technology transfer and venture creation by leveraging DC I-Corps' expertise in the Lean Launch Pad philosophy and curriculum. DC I-Corps benefits from the Site's regional alignment to accelerate the participation of African-Americans in future I-Corps Node cohorts thereby enhancing diversity. I-Corps activities on each campus and assessment of these targeted programs also informs strategies for improving innovation and entrepreneurship interventions aimed at under-represented minorities (URM) and enhance ongoing educational research.

These institutions are uniquely positioned among the HBCUs to undertake this effort. Both institutions are among the inaugural cohort of HBCUs participating in the HBCU Innovation and Entrepreneurship Collaborative (IEC) organized by the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) and the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) to stimulate innovation activity on HBCU campuses. The IEC effort connects HBCUs with best practices to implementing entrepreneurship and innovation activities on campus. These best practices are based on models advocated by Stanford University and the National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance (NCIIA - recently renamed VentureWell), among others. 

The partnership between the Howard and Hampton University Site and the DC I-Corps Node allows for greater opportunities to assess diversity as a variable in innovation and entrepreneurship programming interventions targeting under-represented minorities; enhancing fundamental understanding of effective frameworks for LLP education for diverse populations. Additionally, the Site seeks to increase technical entrepreneurship participation among the HBCU faculty and students by focusing on the following activities:

1.	Increasing the training of HBCU faculty and students in Lean Launchpad methodology.
2.	Developing a strong inter-related network of HBCU entrepreneurs with the NSF I-Corps system. 
3.	Organizing and growing a diverse mentorship network. 
4.	Encouraging applications from in response to NSF I-Corps Regional and National training and/or SBIR solicitations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The HU2 I-Corps Site had 3 principal aims:

  1. Increase the training of HBCU faculty and students in Lean LaunchPad methodology. 
  2. Develop a strong and diverse inter-related network of HBCU entrepreneurs with the NSF I-Corps system. 
  3. Organize and grow a diverse mentorship network. 

 

Over the course of the award, the Site was able to meet each of the articulated aims.


Intellectual Merit

 

Increasing training of faculty and student in Lean LaunchPad methodologies

Site activity exposed over 800 undergraduate students to Lean Startup and Design Thinking methodology by creating new courses, integrating modules into existing courses, and supporting student led extra-curricular activities. On the Howard University campus, the Site led the integration of an Innovation Module in partnership with the USPTO that coupled intellectual property considerations and customer discovery.  The Intro Course is taken by all engineering students on campus.

 

In addition, the Site PIs led the development of 2 interdisciplinary courses – Bison Startup and Bison Accelerate – that were offered on the main campus and at the satellite campus operated in Silicon Valley.  The Silicon Valley campus is notable in that it was a multi-institution program with students from several HBCUs participating in the iteration of the course offered there. A short course with elements from Bison Startup was also launched at Hampton University.

 

I-Corps programming was also integrated into the research infrastructure of each university.  A faculty commercialization program was offered at each institution. At Howard University, working with the Site, a commercialization track was institutionalized into the Research Month program to further support the tech transfer mission of the university.  Faculty and graduate students were able to self-select into the track to make themselves eligible for a commercialization award to assist with market discovery and evaluation.

 

Develop a network of HBCU entrepreneurs with the NSF I-Corps system

The Site was very active in promoting I-Corps throughout the I-Corps network, particularly among HBCUs that were not affiliated with a Node or Site program (and later without affiliation with the Hub program). The Site led or supported programs at 3 of the 6 HBCUs in DC and Maryland and supported teams or faculty from 5 out of the 6 HBCUs in partnership with the DC I-Corps Node.  In addition, the Site worked with community partners in VA (the I-CAP program) to support programming in Hampton Roads and support additional HBCUs beyond Hampton University.

 

To extend its reach beyond the DC-MD-VA area, the Site developed the HBCU I-Corps program which shared the Site’s commercialization training capacity with the broader HBCU network.  Faculty from any of the 101 HBCUs were eligible to take part in the programming and receive financial support for discovery.

 

Teams from 12 HBCUs leveraged the Site’s programming. Over 100 teams participated in Site programming.

 

Organize and grow a diverse mentorship network

During the last year of operation, the HBCU I-Corps program was extended to include a Train-the-Trainer (TTT)program to grow diversity within the regional trainer and mentor ranks. Two TTT cohorts were run in 2022 supporting 21 participants. 8 participants from the cohort have served as regional instructors or mentors, including two in supporting teams at national cohorts.

 

Broader Impacts

The Site met its core aims and, in the process, increased the exposure of HBCU faculty, students and staff to the NSF I-Corps program. Discovery and other innovation activities were integrated across a range of institutional initiatives that extended past the Site partner institutions into a dozen HBCUs. This included the formation and training of I-Corps teams, instructors, and mentors.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2023
Modified by: Grant M Warner
